Error Handling

Proper mechanisms to handle errors are an integral part of modern program languages. Being a modern language, Emojicode provides a sophisticated but light-weight way to handle errors.

The ğŸš¨ Type

Emojicode provides a special error type that is denoted by ğŸš¨. ğŸš¨ is always followed by two other types: An enumeration that serves as the error enumeration indicating the kind of error if one occurs and a contained type â€“ the type that is present if no error arises.

For instance, a method that normally returns a ğŸ”¡ can declare that it will return an instance of ğŸœ in case of an error will declare its return type like this:

ğŸ– ğŸ™… â¡ï¸ ğŸš¨ğŸœğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡

Compatibility of the ğŸš¨ Type

ğŸš¨ types are intentionally not very compatible to enforce prompt error handling and to prevent errors from being passed round too easily. ğŸš¨ types are only compatible to other types with the exact same error enumeration and contained type.

The ğŸš¨ Statement

Inside a method whose return type is an ğŸš¨ type the ğŸš¨ can be used to return an error:

ğŸš¥ Test for Errors

If you want to make sure that an instance of ğŸš¨ does not represent an error but does contain a value you can use the ğŸš¥ expression.

Syntax:

ğŸš¥ expression

ğŸš¥ returns ğŸ‘ if the value is an error or ğŸ‘ false if its not an error and contains a value.

ğŸ¥‘ Error Check Control

ğŸ¥‘ variable expression
  block
ğŸ“ variable
  block

ğŸš‡ Perfect Values

If you are sure that an ğŸš¨ instance will never represent an error you can use the ğŸš‡ expression to the take contained value without prior error checking.

Syntax:

ğŸš‡ expression

If, tough, the ğŸš¨ instance represents an error at runtime the program will abort with a run-time error similar to:

ğŸš¨ Fatal Error: Unexpectedly found ğŸš¨ with value 2.
